number of helpful: 71 of 73 people (97%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2016
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two Original Release: 2008 Genre Tags: RPG; Adventure; Parody; Comedy My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-10 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Casual gamers REVIEWOn the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two is not as challenging as the first game, but it continues the narrative and tradition of the first. It boasts solidly designed and enjoyable RPG elements, with a light and hilarious story.  This is a good pick-up for any casual RPG fans out there looking for some lighthearted fun.Like the first game, technically, this is a parody game— but to be honest it plays better than many modern “real” RPGs that are emerging from the indie realm.  It plays like an old-school, turnbased-combat RPG, complete with leveling-up elements and a mild form of gear upgrading.  The gameplay is definitely fun and the RPG elements will keep you addicted to the progression.  You will find yourself striving to reach that next milestone of development as you play through the hilarious campaign.On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two is a Penny Arcade game. The story is fun and funny; it doesn’t take itself too seriously.  It is very lighthearted and the game is packed with hilarious and immature humor.  The characters are likeable, and cartoonish.  The art style is charming and fits the atmosphere of the game perfectly.  It all comes together as a very comic-like production.This is a good second chapter to the first game.  There is really nothing drastically different in this one compared to the first, but that’s not really a bad thing because the first was pretty good.  As they say: “if it ain’t broke…”I strongly recommend playing both Episode One and Episode Two in order and together, as they are more two parts to a whole than they are two separate games.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
, 2012
												On the Rain Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two picks up shortly after the events of the first game. Once again, you (your character from the first episode can be imported) team up with 1920's-era Gabe & Tycho to stop an apocolyptic menace. Everything I said in my recommendation of the first game once again holds here, because this is pretty much the exact same game - literally, it uses the same engine, combat, mechanics, style, etc. The only things that have changed are the locations and enemies. So just take my previous review, replace "slaughtering hobos, clowns and mimes" with "slaughtering mental patients, pretentious rich folks and giant spiders", and there ya go. But that's not to say there's anything wrong with this - it works in an episodic format. So once again, if you are a fan of PA (their humor or characters) and adventure-RPGs, this is worth a look, despite the rough edges. I'm now looking forward to the recently announced Episode Three!

content:
ber 10, 2012
												Loses a lot of the JRPG focus and seems to be conflicted with trying to be a point-and-click adventure game. Tedious pixel hunting quests, overly difficult QTE combat, and a boring story with little focus really kills the potential this game had. Although it continues off from the previous game (game mechanic and level-wise), you lose all your old skills for some reason. More frustration comes from a long fetch quest chain that rewards you with a jail cell. Combat is absurd with enemies getting mountains of health plus free "interrupt" heals, removing strategy from combat and requiring you to just pile everything onto one enemy at time. The last boss is a multi-part "gimme" fight, that ends in a lame adventure game last fight that requires no skill and cuts out your party.Overall this was really disappointing, boring and tedious. Just pick up the first one and pretend ep2 doesn't exist.

content:
y 18, 2014
												The gang from Penny Arcade are back in this sequel. And as such, here's a review!Story- You return as your created character (if you wish) and in trying to rebuild your home after saving the world, Gabe and Tycho return (again destroying your house) and beg for your aid in their latest supernatural case. Again, you now travel around the city looking for a new place to live while saving the world from a tyranical (and fruit-horny robot god). Again, following the same gothic, lovecraftian style of comedy and horror, the story draws you into its world and its characters. But, as in the first game, it will only do so for a couple of hours before the credits roll. A-Graphics- The game is exactly the same as its predicessor. Nothing truly great but works well with what it's got. D+Sound- The voice actor for the narrator still does a terrific job and still has that dry wit. Music is recycled from the first game, not a bad thing but nothing really new either. C-Gameplay- Still needs a controller option and still suffers the same problems. The battles are similar but the mini games that powers up the special attacks are different, which is good. Not an improvement but switches things up a bit. COverall- I kinda got lazy with this review but really, it is a continuation of the first game so I really can't say anything new about it. It's fun, and I like the fact that you can transfer your created character from the first game. Also, it does keep you intrested in it and makes you want to see what happens in the next episode. So... buy it and enjoy. C

												Episode 2 done.Hoes, Double Barrle Shotguns, Fists of Fury! Fighting MONKEYS. MECHA ROBOT BATTLE! What more could you want from a game. Sadly, as the protagonist you are still without a place to call home. First a giant robot, then a truck. What next. You finally find a place and it gets burned down to the ground. As the anger dwells inside you the more powerful you and your hoe become!. As you complete this episode, one thought continually crosses your mind, whats the plan, where am I going to sleep tonight.Worth playing in my opinion. Just be sure to play through Episode 1 before picking up Episode 2. As your quest to find a bed to sleep on and shelter to keep you warm continue,Cya next time in Ep 3.

The writing in these games, courtesy of Penny Arcade writer Jerry Holkins, is everything you'd expect, but unfortunately you'll have to put up with a turn-based JRPG of sorts to see much of it. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2012
												Episode 2 of On the Rain Slick Precipice of Darkness continues the eldritch adventures of Tycho, Gabe, and your character from the first episode in their quest to avert catastrophe at the hands of giant robots with an obscene attraction towards fruit. As expected, it follows most of the conventions established in the first game as far as adventuring and combat goes, with only a few minor changes in terms of item function and cast. Overall, a good game for anyone looking for an adventure of only a few hours or for those who enjoy the style and humor of the Penny Arcade webcomic.As of mid-2012 (around the time of Episode 3's release), numerous players on Windows 7 machines were reporting being unable to get past the games start menu. Although neither Hothead Games nor Steam Support were able to help assauge this problem, it ultimately proved to be solvable by running it in compatibility mode with Windows 95.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
r 18, 2016
												Penny Arcade Adventures Episode One was a game that had some good elements, but ultimately felt soulless and boring. Penny Arcade Adventures Episode Two had the exact same elements and was able to craft a much better game out of what it was given. There was very little changed from Episode One to Episode Two, but what little was changed made all the difference in the world. Penny Arcade Adventures: On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness: Episode Two is basically everything the first game should have been. Despite the fact that it is far from a perfect title, I can still safely recommend Episode Two, and if you enjoyed Episode One, then you are in for even more of a treat with this game.Full Review Here http://www.gamefaqs.com/PC/952842-penny-arcade-adventures-episode-two/reviews/156947

content:
r 18, 2016
												Penny Arcade Adventures Episode One was a game that had some good elements, but ultimately felt soulless and boring. Penny Arcade Adventures Episode Two had the exact same elements and was able to craft a much better game out of what it was given. There was very little changed from Episode One to Episode Two, but what little was changed made all the difference in the world. Penny Arcade Adventures: On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness: Episode Two is basically everything the first game should have been. Despite the fact that it is far from a perfect title, I can still safely recommend Episode Two, and if you enjoyed Episode One, then you are in for even more of a treat with this game.Full Review Here http://www.gamefaqs.com/PC/952842-penny-arcade-adventures-episode-two/reviews/156947
